unnormalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey into Ayurveda Treatments
normalised: ## Finding My Balance: A Journey into Ayurveda Treatments

unnormalised: The incessant hum of Mumbai, the relentless deadlines, the pressure cooker existence – it was all starting to take its toll. I, like so many others, was constantly juggling responsibilities, feeling frayed at the edges. My usual coping mechanisms weren't cutting it. That's when my grandmother, Amma, suggested something: Ayurveda.

unnormalised: Amma, a staunch believer in the ancient wisdom of Ayurveda, insisted I visit a reputable center. "Beta, modern medicine is good, but sometimes you need to go back to your roots," she’d said. So, on the auspicious day of 23/10/2023, I found myself at the Dhanvantari Ayurveda Clinic in Kerala.
normalised: Amma, a staunch believer in the ancient wisdom of Ayurveda, insisted I visit a reputable center. "Beta, modern medicine is good, but sometimes you need to go back to your roots," she’d said. So, on the auspicious day of twenty third October two thousand and twenty three, I found myself at the Dhanvantari Ayurveda Clinic in Kerala.

unnormalised: The initial consultation was a revelation. Dr. Nair, a gentle and knowledgeable Vaidya, spent a good hour understanding my *prakriti* (body constitution). He diagnosed a Vata imbalance, explaining how my erratic lifestyle was exacerbating it. The treatment plan he prescribed was holistic: Abhyanga (oil massage), Shirodhara (oil pouring on the forehead), and a customized diet plan.

unnormalised: Initially, I was skeptical. Could a simple oil massage really make a difference? But after a week of consistent treatments, something shifted. The tension in my shoulders began to melt away. The incessant mental chatter quieted down. I even started waking up naturally at 06:00 hrs, feeling refreshed!

unnormalised: The diet was another eye-opener. Swapping my usual chai and toast for a warm bowl of kitchari felt surprisingly nourishing. Cutting down on processed foods and incorporating more seasonal vegetables, as suggested by Dr. Nair, made a noticeable difference in my energy levels. I learned to appreciate the grounding power of spices like turmeric and ginger in my daily routine. My skin also started glowing!

unnormalised: One particularly memorable experience was the Nasya treatment. At exactly 11:00 am on 28/10/2023, the assistant carefully administered medicated oil through my nostrils. It was a strange sensation, but afterward, I felt clearer and less congested than I had in months.
normalised: One particularly memorable experience was the Nasya treatment. unnormalised: My two-week Ayurvedic retreat cost me around Rs. 45,000, but honestly, it was an investment in my well-being. I’m now back in Mumbai, trying my best to incorporate Ayurvedic principles into my daily life. It’s not always easy, but even small changes, like a daily oil massage or a mindful cup of herbal tea at 16:00 hrs, make a difference. The journey to balance continues, and I'm grateful for the guidance of Ayurveda.
